abstract.text: The exclusive diffractive production of vector mesons and real photons in ep collisions has been studied at HERA in a wide kinematic range.
The most recent experimental results are presented.

body_text.text: Introduction
The diffractive scattering is a process where the colliding particles scatter at very small angles and without any color flux in the final state.
This involves a propagator carrying the vacuum quantum numbers, called Pomeron and described, in the soft regime, within the Regge theory.
The discovery of a big amount of diffractive events in DIS regime provided a hard scale which can be varied over a wide range and therefore it is an ideal testing for QCD models.
In particular, the diffractive production of Vector Mesons (VMs) and real photons in ep collisions allows to study the transition from the soft to the hard regime in strong interactions.

The hard regime (high energy and low Bjorken-x) is dominated by the exchange of a hard Pomeron well described by perturbative QCD (pQCD), while at low-x the interaction is well described within the Regge phenomenology.

Indicating with Q 2 the virtuality of the exchanged photon and with M 2 the square mass of the produced VM, HERA data suggested a universal hard scale, Q 2 + M 2 , for the diffractive exclusive pruduction of VM and real photons, which indicates the transition from the soft to the hard regime.
Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section
A new precision measurement of the reaction γ * p → ρ 0 p was published by ZEUS 1 .
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: It was found that the cross section falls steeply with the increas-ing of Q 2 but, unlike it was observed for the J/ψ electroproduction 2,3 , it cannot be described by a simple propagator term like σ ∝ (Q 2 + M 2 ) −n , in particular an n value increasing with Q 2 appears to be favored.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: Figure 1 reports the cross section for the ρ 0 electroproduction versus Q 2 compared with several theoretical predictions: the KWM model 4 based on the saturation model, the FSS model 5 with and without saturation and the DF model 6 .
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: None of the available models gives a good description of the data over the full kinematic range of the measurement.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: The soft to hard transition can be observed looking at the dependence of the VM photoproduction (Q 2 = 0) cross section from the γ * p centre of mass energy, W , where the scale is provided by M 2 .
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: Figure 2 collects the σ(γ * p → V p) as a function of W from the lightest vector meson, ρ 0 , to the heaviest, Υ, compared to the total cross section.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: The cross section rises with the energy as W δ , where the δ exponent increases with the hard scale M 2 as expected for a transition from the soft to the hard regime.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: New results on the Υ photoproduction 7 , recently published by ZEUS, confirmed the steeper rise of σ(W ) for higher vector meson masses.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: The transition from the soft to the hard regime can also be studied varying Q 2 .
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: Recent results were achieved by H1 8 and ZEUS 9 for the exclusive production of a real photon, the Deeply Virtual Compton Scattering (DVCS), where the hard scale is provided only by the photon virtuality, Q 2 .
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: Figure 3 shows the H1 (left) and the ZEUS (right) results.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: The steep rise with W of the cross section even at low-Q 2 , seems to suggest that the most sensitive part to the soft scale comes from the wave function of the pruduced VM.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: A similar result was obtained for the J/ψ electroproduction 2,3 .
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: The electroproduction of a large variety of VMs was studied at different Q 2 values and the corresponding slope δ is reported in Fig. 4 (left) versus the scale Q 2 + M 2 , including the DVCS measurements.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: Data show a logarithmic shape σ ∝ ln(Q 2 + M 2 ) and the behaviour seems to be universal with δ increasing from 0.2 at low scale, as expected from a soft Pomeron exchange 10 to ∼ 0.8 at large scale values.
body_text.section: Q 2 and W dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: t dependence of the cross section
The differential cross section as a function of t can be parametrised by a fit dσ d|t| ∝ e b|t| .
body_text.section: t dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: The measurement of dσ/d|t| for the DVCS process, recentrly published by the H1 Collab 8 , where t was obtained from the transverse momentum distribution of the photon, studied b versus Q 2 and W as shown in Fig. 5.
body_text.section: t dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: b seems to decrease with Q 2 up to the value expected for a hard process but it doesn't depend on W .
body_text.section: t dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: A new preliminary ZEUS measurement 9 of dσ/d|t| has been achieved from a direct measurement of the proton final Since b value can be related via a Fourier transform to the impact parameter and assuming that the exclusive process in the hard regime is dominated by gluons, the relation r 2 = b( c) 2 can be used to obtain the radius of the gluon confinement area in the proton.
body_text.section: t dependence of the cross section

body_text.text: b ∼ 5 GeV 2 corresponds to r 2 ∼ 0.6 f m smaller than the proton radius (∼ 0.8 f m) indicating that the gluons are well contained within the charge-radius of the proton.
